abstract.text: A type that encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can feed
actions back to the

inlineContent.text: Effects are the perfect place to do side effects, such as network requests, saving/loading
from disk, creating timers, interacting with dependencies, and more. They are returned from
reducers so that the
can perform the effects after the reducer is done running.
There are 2 distinct ways to create an
: one using Swift’s native concurrency tools, and
the other using Apple’s Combine framework:
If using Swift’s native structured concurrency tools then there are 3 main ways to create an
effect, depending on if you want to emit one single action back into the system, or any number
of actions, or just execute some work without emitting any actions:
If using Combine in your application, in particular for the dependencies of your feature
then you can create effects by making use of any of Combine’s operators, and then erasing the
publisher type to
with either
or
. Note that
the Combine interface to
is considered soft deprecated, and you should
eventually port to Swift’s native concurrency tools.
is not thread safe, and so all effects must receive values on the same
thread. This is typically the main thread,
and
if the store is being used to drive UI then
it must receive values on the main thread.
This is only an issue if using the Combine interface of
as mentioned
above. If  you are using Swift’s concurrency tools and the
and
functions on
, then threading is automatically handled for you.

abstract.text: Execute an operation with a cancellation identifier.
Turns an effect into one that is capable of being canceled.
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if
any.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
Creates an effect that executes some work in the real world that doesn’t need to feed data
back into the store. If an error is thrown, the effect will complete and the error will be
ignored.
Merges a sequence of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects at the same
time.
An effect that causes a test to fail if it runs.
Wraps the emission of each element with SwiftUI’s
Concatenates a variadic list of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects
one after the other.
Concatenates a collection of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects one
after the other.
A
is an object that can observe state changes and send actions. They are most
commonly used in views, such as SwiftUI views, UIView or UIViewController, but they can be used
anywhere it makes sense to observe state or send actions.
Review unsupported effect APIs and their replacements.
An effect that will cancel any currently in-flight effect with the given identifier.
Wraps an asynchronous unit of work in an effect.
A convenience type alias for referring to an effect that can never fail, like the kind of
returned by a reducer after processing an action.
An effect that will cancel multiple currently in-flight effects with the given identifiers.
Transforms all elements from the upstream effect with a provided closure.
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
An effect that does nothing and completes immediately. Useful for situations where you must
return an effect, but you don’t need to do anything.
Merges this effect and another into a single effect that runs both at the same time.
An effect that will cancel multiple currently in-flight effects with the given identifiers.
Concatenates this effect and another into a single effect that first runs this effect, and
after it completes or is cancelled, runs the other.
Wraps an asynchronous unit of work that can emit any number of times in an effect.
A value that represents either a success or a failure. This type differs from Swift’s
type in that it uses only one generic for the success case, leaving the failure case as an
untyped
Merges a variadic list of effects together into a single effect, which runs the effects at the
same time.
A generic wrapper for turning any non-
type into a
one, in an unchecked
manner.

actions back to the
Turns an effect into one that is capable of being canceled.
